item.title: Identifying Geolocation of Attacker using Wireshark
item.description:
Forensic Context

This walkthrough uses the WebStrike scenario from CyberDefenders.

Artifact: PCAP file containing network traffic
Goal: Identify the attacker’s geographic location

Note: To learn how to acquire PCAP files, see DocuSign’s documentation on How to do a Packet Capture (PCAP).

First, establish the victim IP. You can identify your own IP using:

curl ifconfig.me

Or via What Is My IP.

Finding the Attacker IP

With the victim IP established, identify network conversations in Wireshark: Statistics → Conversations.

item.title: Brand New to Cyber?
item.description:
The cybersecurity job market is rough right now. AI hype, a shaky economy, ghost jobs, and endless LinkedIn “wins” make rejection feel personal. If you’re new and struggling to break in, hear this first:

You’re not broken.

I’m not here to give resume hacks or interview tricks. What I can offer is perspective. Everyone enters cybersecurity differently. This is how I got into DFIR—and what actually mattered.

How It Started

I’ve always liked computers. In high school, I tried to take apart our family PC and learned why static electricity kills hardware. That was our only computer, and replacing it wasn’t an option.
